Notwithstanding any other provision of this division, the governing body shall be authorized, by a majority vote, to waive the solicitation of bids for any purchases of used equipment in amounts not exceeding $50,000.00 if the following requirements with respect to such proposed purchase are met: (1) The equipment to be purchased is used; (2) The equipment to be purchased is in such condition that it may be, upon delivery, immediately put in operation by the county department to which such equipment is assigned without substantial repairs; (3) The used equipment must be either offered for sale directly by another governmental entity, by or through an online bid site used primarily by governmental entities for the sale of used equipment, or from a private vendor; (4) It must be verified prior to approval of the purchase that the purchase price is consistent with current market prices of similar used equipment as established by recent sales, published valuations, and other verifiable sources of price information; (5) There must be a determination by the board of commissioners that there is an immediate necessity for the purchase of such equipment so that requiring normal bid processes would potentially jeopardize the public health or safety; (6) The purchase price of the used equipment does not exceed $50,000.00. No purchase of used equipment shall be divided into its component parts in an attempt to meet the $50,000.00 purchase price limit under this section. Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, no purchase of used equipment shall be authorized unless funds for such purchase have been appropriated in the current annual county budget. (Ord. of 11-12-2013(1)) Editor's note— Ord. of 11-12-2013(1) set out provisions intended for use as § 2-259. To avoid duplication of section numbers, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 2-261. Sec. 2-262. - Use of purchasing cards and credit cards by county elected officials. (a) Intent and scope. This section is intended to comply with the policy requirements of O.C.G.A. § 36-80-24 regarding the use of county issued government purchasing cards and credit cards. (b) Definitions. Authorized elected official means an elected official designated by public vote of the board of commissioners to receive a county issued government purchasing card or credit card. Card administrator means the purchasing card and credit card administrator designated by the Lee Board of Commissioners. County means Lee County and/or the board of commissioners. County purchase card, county p-card, or county credit card means a financial transaction card issued by any business organization, financial institution, or any duly authorized agent of such organization or institution, used by a county official to purchase goods, services and other things of value on behalf of the county. Financial transaction card means an instrument or device as the term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-9-30(5). User agreement means the required agreement between the board of commissioners and the authorized elected officials which restricts the use of a county purchasing card or credit card. (c) Designated elected officials. The Lee County Board of Commissioners ("county"), in its discretion, may authorize specific county elected officials to use a county purchasing card or credit card by adoption of a resolution in a public meeting. No authorized elected official may use a county purchasing card or credit card until and unless he or she has executed the county's purchasing card and credit card user agreement. The county will not make payments to any business organization, financial institution, or any duly authorized agent of such organization or institution, for amounts charged by an elected official to any purchasing cards or credit cards that are not issued pursuant to this section or for any purchases that are not authorized by this section. (d) Card administrator. The board of commissioners shall designate a county purchasing card and credit card administrator. The responsibilities of the card administrator include: (1) Manage county issued purchasing cards and credit cards. (2) Serve as the main point of contact for all county purchasing card and credit card issues. (3) Serve as liaison to the elected officials authorized to use a purchasing card or credit card and their staff, as well as to the issuer of the purchasing card or credit card. (4) Provide training on card policies and procedures to the elected officials authorized to use a purchasing card or credit card and their staff. (5) Develop internal procedures to ensure timely payment of cards. (6) Assist authorized elected officials to dispute transactions when necessary. (7) Establish internal procedures to ensure compliance with this section, county procurement ordinances and policies, county purchasing card and credit card user agreements, applicable agreements with the business organization, financial institution, or any duly authorized agent of such organization or institution, issuing card, and state law, specifically, O.C.G.A. §§ 16-9-37 and 36-80-24. (8) Document internal controls, audits and other measures to prevent and detect misuse or abuse of the cards. (9) Audit and reconcile transactions monthly. (10) Maintain records for at least seven years or as otherwise provided by the county's record retention policy. (e) Use of cards. (1) Authorized purchases. County purchase cards and credit cards may be used to purchase goods and services directly related to the public duties of the authorized elected official only. All purchases are subject to the terms of this section, the county purchasing card and credit card user agreement, county procurement policies and ordinances, and the adopted budget. Only authorized elected officials may use a county purchase card or credit card for purchases or payments. The cards, and use of the cards, are not transferrable to employees. The authorized elected official shall use care to ensure that others do not have access to the card account number, expiration date and security code. Unless otherwise approved by the governing authority or established in the county purchasing card and credit card user agreement, the transaction limits are as follows: Per transaction: $1,000.00 Per month: $5,000.00 (2) Unauthorized purchases. County purchasing cards and credit cards shall not be used for goods and services not directly related to the official responsibilities of the authorized elected official. Additionally, cards shall not be used to avoid compliance with the county's purchasing ordinances and procedures, to purchase goods and services that are not approved in the county's budget, to purchase goods and services exceeding the per transaction or per month limit, or to make purchases not in compliance with the county purchasing card and credit card user agreement. (3) Receipts and documentation. Receipts, invoices and other supporting documentation of all purchases made with a county purchasing card or credit card shall be obtained and maintained by the authorized county elected official for five years or as otherwise provided by the county's record retention policy. If an original or duplicate cannot be produced, a sworn affidavit of the authorized elected official may be substituted. The documentation must include the supplier or merchant information (i.e., name and location), quantity, description, unit price, total price, price paid without sales tax and an explanation of the purchase sufficient to show that the expense was in the performance of official county duties. (4) Public records. All receipt and other documentation of purchases are public records and subject to the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70 et seq. (f) Review of purchases and audit. Proper documentation of purchases, internal controls and other measures prevent and allow detection to misuse or abuse of county issued purchase cards and credit cards. Authorized elected officials and staff that process payments under this program shall cooperate and comply with the procedures established by the county. (1) Review of purchases. All purchases shall be reviewed according to the following procedure: Purchases will be reviewed and signed off on by the elected official or a designated supervisor in the elected official's office. Once the purchases have been signed off on it is the responsibility of the elected official or designated employee of that office to ensure all required supporting documentation is submitted to accounts payable in a timely manner to allow the bill to be paid on time. (2) Audits . The card administrator shall perform an annual review of the card program to ensure adequacy of internal policies and procedures, cardholder spending limits, monthly reconciliation procedures and documentation for transactions. Elected officials and staff shall cooperate with such review. (g) Violations . (1) An elected official shall reimburse the county for any purchases made with a county issued purchase card or credit card in violation of this section or the user agreement. (2) In the discretion of the county governing authority, failure to comply with the procedures outlined in this section may result in: a. A warning; b. Suspension of the elected official's authority to use a county purchase card or credit card; or c. Revocation of the elected official's authority to use a county purchase card or credit card. (3) Nothing in this section shall preclude the county governing authority from referring misuse of a purchase card or credit card for prosecution to the appropriate authorities. ( Ord. of 12-8-2015(1), Exh. A ) Sec. 2-263. - Purchasing from vendors located within Lee County. Notwithstanding any other provision of Division 2 of Chapter 2, Article VI of the Code of Ordinances, the board of commissioners shall be authorized, but not required, to purchase from local vendors whenever the bid price or proposed price is from the lowest responsive and responsible bidder or whenever the bid price or proposed price differential between a local vendor and the lowest responsive and responsible bidder or proposal is no more than five percent of the total price. If more than one local vendor would qualify to be selected as the successful bidder under this section, then the board of commissioners shall select the local vendor which is the lowest responsive and responsible bidder previously providing the most satisfactory work for Lee County. For purposes of this section, the term "local vendor" shall include a vendor or proposed vendor whose principal offices are located either within Lee County or within a city or county contiguous to Lee County. Nothing in the section shall be construed to conflict with the provisions of the Georgia Local Government Public Works Construction Law at O.C.G.A. § 36-9-1 et seq. and in the event of a conflict with such statute, such statute shall prevail. ( Ord. of 5-24-2016 ) ARTICLE VII. - PLANNING COMMISSION DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 2-264—2-275. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PLANNING COMMISSION
Sec. 2-276. - Established. The Lee County-Leesburg-Smithville Planning Commission, referred to in this division as the "planning commission," is established and reestablished effective as of the date establish in accord with the provisions of section 2-291. (Ord. of 4-18-2005) Sec. 2-277. - Prior acts ratified. All acts of the planning commission as the commission was constituted prior to March 1, 2005, are ratified and approved by the board of commissioners. All existing members of the planning commission having been appointed in the same manner as provided in this division as of January, 2005 for four-year terms commencing January 1, 2005, such appointments are ratified as of the effective date of this division, and such member so appointed shall continue to serve out their respective terms in accord with the terms of the division. (Ord. of 4-18-2005) Sec. 2-278. - Membership. (a) The planning commission shall consist of a board of seven members appointed by the jurisdictions in the following manner: five board members shall be appointed by the board of commissioners of the county, with each county commissioner nominating one person residing in that county commissioner's district, and the board of commissioners ratifying, by majority vote, such nomination. In the event that such nomination is not ratified by majority vote, then the county commissioner shall nominate another person from such county commissioner's commission district. One board member shall be appointed by majority vote by the governing body of the City of Leesburg, and one board member shall be appointed by majority vote by the governing body of the City of Smithville. In the event that a planning commission member moves his or her residence to a location outside of the appointing jurisdiction or outside of the district in which such member resided at the time of such member taking office, then the seat of such member shall be declared vacant, and the appointing authority shall appoint another person qualified for membership on the commission to fill the unexpired term of such member. (b) Planning commission members shall be appointed for four-year terms; provided, however, with respect to the members of the planning commission appointed hereunder, beginning with the appointments to the planning commission to be made in December, 2008, or January 2009, three of the members appointed by the county commission shall be appointed for initial terms of two years, and two of the members appointed by the county commission shall be appointed for initial terms of four years. Each member appointed by the governing body of Leesburg and the governing body of Smithville shall be appointed for initial terms of four years. Thereafter, all members shall be appointed for terms of four years. Nothing shall prevent a member from succeeding himself, and, except as otherwise provided herein, all members of the planning commission shall hold office for the term specified and until the appropriate governing body shall have appointed such member's successor. Any vacancy on the planning commission shall be filled in the same manner as the position was filled prior to the occurrence of the vacancy for the unexpired term of the member. (c) Any member of the planning commission may be removed from office by a two-thirds vote of the local governing body which appointed such member in the event that such member is arrested for or convicted of a felony, a misdemeanor of a high and aggravated nature, or a crime involving turpitude, is found by the appointing authority to be guilty of misfeasance or malfeasance in office, is found to have failed to attend more than three successive regular meetings of the planning commission without justification or excuse, or for any other reason that the governing body which appointed such member determines is appropriate grounds for removal of such member from the planning commission. (Ord. of 4-18-2005) Sec. 2-279. - Election of chairman; duties. (a) The planning commission shall elect from its members a chairman. This officer shall be elected for a term of one year and may be re-elected. Elections for such office shall be held at the regular meeting in January of each year. (b) The chairman shall preside at all regular meetings of the planning commission and at all other meetings and public hearings as called by the planning commission. He shall call special meetings of the planning commission in accordance with provisions of this article. He shall sign all documents authorized by the planning commission and transmit reports, plans and recommendations of the planning commission to the appropriate governing authority, and, in general, act as spokesman for the planning commission. He may also appoint committees, and the chairs thereof, as the chairman determines may be necessary to perform the tasks of the planning commission. (Ord. of 4-18-2005) Sec. 2-280. - Election of vice-chairman; duties. (a) The planning commission shall elect from its members a vice-chairman. This officer shall be elected for a term of one year and may be re-elected. Elections for such office shall be held at the regular meeting in January of each year. (b) The vice-chairman shall serve as chairman in the absence of the chairman. In the event of the resignation or disability of the chairman, or in the event of a vacancy in the chairmanship, the vice-chairman shall serve as chairman until a new chairman is elected by the planning commission membership to serve the remaining term of the chairman. He shall also serve as ex-officio member of all committees appointed by the chairman. (Ord. of 4-18-2005) Sec. 2-281. - Meetings; when held. (a) The regular monthly meeting of the planning commission shall be held at a date and time designated annually at the first meeting in January in the county administration building, or at such other public location as the planning commission, by majority vote, may deem appropriate. At its meetings the planning commission shall consider all matters properly brought before it. A regular or called meeting may be canceled or re-scheduled by the planning commission at a prior meeting, or under special circumstances, such as the lack of agenda items for a particular meeting, may be cancelled or re-scheduled by the chairman, but the chairman shall give notice of such cancellation or re-scheduling as soon as practicable to the members of the planning commission and to the local legal organ by the most appropriate means available under the circumstances. (b) The chairman may call special meetings at any time for the consideration and determination of any questions or matters requiring immediate attention of the planning commission. The zoning and codes administrator shall give the members at least 24 hours advanced notice of each such special meeting. (c) Nothing in this section shall prevent the planning commission from amending its meeting schedule from time to time, or from having less than one meeting in any given month due to such reasons as the planning commission may deem proper. (d) All meetings of the planning commission shall be held in accord with the provisions of the Georgia Open Meetings Act. (Ord. of 4-18-2005) Sec. 2-282. - Quorum. At any meeting of the planning commission a quorum shall consist of four members of the planning commission, except as otherwise provided herein. No action shall be taken in the absence of a quorum. If there exists a vacancy on the planning commission that has not yet been filled at the time of any meeting of the planning commission, a quorum of the planning commission shall be a majority of the commission members then actually serving on the commission. (Ord. of 4-18-2005) Sec. 2-283. - Voting on questions before the planning commission. (a) Each member of the planning commission, including the chairman and any other presiding officer, shall be a voting member. Each member shall vote upon each matter before the planning commission that is put to the membership for a vote, and there shall be no abstentions from voting on a matter, unless such member is disqualified from voting in accord with the provisions of this division. There shall be no absentee voting nor proxy voting. Voting shall be done by voice or show of hands. Any member shall be authorized to require that the ayes and nays be recorded in the minutes with respect to any particular vote. In the event that any member shall have a personal interest of any kind, whether financial or otherwise, in a matter before the planning commission, that member shall disclose his interest and be disqualified from either debating the matter at a planning commission meeting or voting upon the matter, and it shall be recorded in the minutes that no vote was cast by such member. Nothing herein shall prevent a member of the planning commission from presenting a matter to the planning commission where such member is the applicant in the matter before the planning commission so long as such status is disclosed by the member prior to the presentation of the matter to the planning commission, but such member shall still refrain from voting on such matter. In the event a member does not disclose his interest in a matter prior to voting on that matter before the planning commission and the planning commission finds there was a personal interest, the planning commission may, by majority vote, refer the matter to the governing body which appointed such member for consideration by the governing body as to whether such member should be removed as a member of the planning commission. In all events, the members of the planning commission shall strive to comply with all relevant statues, rules, and regulations related to the ethical conduct of members of boards and commissions, including, but not limited to, the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 45-10-3. (b) The affirmative vote of a majority of those then serving on the planning commission shall be necessary for the recommendation of adoption of any amendment to the zoning ordinance, for approval of any recommendation on any other codes, ordinances or resolutions adopted by the planning commission, or for the approval of any other matter coming before the planning commission, unless specifically provided otherwise in this division. With respect to any matter before the planning commission where the planning commission has final authority to approve or disapprove an application or request, in the event that the planning commission does not act on the matter by either approving or rejecting the application or request within 60 calendar days of the date that the application was filed with the appropriate county planning department, then the application shall stand approved without further action by the planning commission. In computing such time period, the date of filing shall not be counted. (Ord. of 4-18-2005) Sec. 2-284. - Agenda. (a) As required by the Georgia Open Meetings Act, the planning commission shall conduct its meetings based upon an agenda of the items to be considered by the planning commission. Such agenda may be submitted to the members of the planning commission prior to or at the time of the planning commission meeting. Any member may make a motion to add any item to the agenda; and if there is a second to that motion, and if the motion is approved by a majority vote of the planning commission members then voting, the board may consider, discuss, debate, table or take final action as to such motion. (b) The agenda for each planning commission meeting shall be prepared by the county planning director, or his designee, and any member of the planning commission who desires to have an item placed on the agenda for consideration shall contact the planning director and advise him that such item should be placed upon the agenda at least 24 hours prior to the time of the planning commission meeting at which the planning commission member desires such item to be considered. (c) Upon completion of the preparation and printing of the agenda, it shall be considered a public record and shall be open for inspection by the public pursuant to the state open records law. (Ord. of 4-18-2005) Sec. 2-285. - Applications to the planning commission to be in writing. All applications, petitions, or other requests to the commission from a citizen or an interested party must be in writing and signed by the applicant or an agent of the applicant. (Ord. of 4-18-2005) Sec. 2-286. - Robert's Rules of Order adopted. The meetings of the planning commission shall be governed by the provisions of this division and by the by-laws, if any, of the planning commission. In the event that a particular procedural issue is not addressed in this division or in the by-laws of the planning commission, then the planning commission shall be guided and governed by those parliamentary rules and regulations known as Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, being adopted and made a part of this section as though fully set out in the section. In the event of a conflict between a county ordinance and Robert's Rules of Order, the county ordinance shall control. (Ord. of 4-18-2005) Sec. 2-287. - Planning department to maintain original applications. The original of each application or request to be submitted to the planning commission shall be filed with the planning director, who shall note on the application the date and time of its submittal and the vote for or against the approval of the application or request. Such original applications and requests shall be retained by the planning department in a file maintained for such purposes. Minutes of all meetings of the planning commission shall be taken and prepared by the county planning director, or his designee, in accord with the Georgia Open Meeting Act. Such minutes shall be reviewed and approved, with such revisions as are approved by majority vote of the members of the planning commission, by majority vote at the next regular meeting of the planning commission. (Ord. of 4-18-2005) Sec. 2-288. - Compensation. The members of the planning commission shall receive compensation for their services as planning commission members, as established from time to time, by the board of commissioners; provided; however, that the compensation, if any, of any one or more members of the planning commission may not be reduced during the term that such member or members is then serving. (Ord. of 4-18-2005) Sec. 2-289. - Bylaws. The planning commission may establish bylaws and regulations for the governing of the commission. The planning commission shall have perpetual existence; provided, however, that nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit the board of commissioners from amending, revising, or repealing the provisions of this division should the board of commissioners deem it appropriate to do so. (Ord. of 4-18-2005) Sec. 2-290. - Joint contract. The planning commission shall be authorized to commence its duties upon the appointment of all of the members thereof pursuant to section 2-278 hereof. The board of commissioners, the governing authority the City of Leesburg, and the governing authority of the City of Smithville shall enter into an intergovernmental contract which shall govern the establishment, funding, and duties of the planning commission, and such contract shall be binding upon the planning commission to the fullest extent authorized by law. In the event that one or more of said cities do not adopt said intergovernmental contract, or in the event that one or more of said cities withdraw from said intergovernmental contract after its adoption, then this division shall continue in effect as to the governmental entity or entities which remain parties to such intergovernmental contract, and if no governmental entities remain a party to such intergovernmental contract, then this division shall remain in effect solely with respect to matters under the planning commission's jurisdiction which relate to property or issues located in the unincorporated areas of the county. Notwithstanding the foregoing, any governmental entity which withdraws from said intergovernmental contract shall not be authorized to appoint any members to the planning commission, the membership of any member of the planning commission appointed by such withdrawing local governmental entity shall be terminated and declared vacant as of the date of such withdrawal, and the board of commissioners of the county shall be authorized to appoint a member to fill the unexpired term of such member from persons residing in the unincorporated areas of the county. (Ord. of 4-18-2005) Sec. 2-291. - Effective date. This division shall become effective upon its adoption by the governing body of the county, by the governing body of the City of Leesburg, and by the governing body of the City of Smithville. Notice of the adoption of this division by such cities shall be provided by the respective city clerks of such cities to the county planning director, and the effective date hereof shall be established as the latest date that this division was approved by such cities. (Ord. of 4-18-2005) Secs. 2-292—2-299. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - INDIGENT DEFENSE SERVICES[9]
Footnotes: --- (9) --- Editor's note— Ord. of March 8, 2005 amended the Code with the addition of a new article VII, sections 2-300-2-304. In order to avoid duplication of article numbers, the provisions of said ordinance have been included herein as article VIII, sections 2-300—2-304, at the discretion of the editor.
Sec. 2-300. - Application for indigent defense services. Each person lacking the financial ability to provide for themselves representation in his of her defense in criminal proceedings in the magistrate court of the county or the probate court of the county, and desiring that the county provide such services to him or her, shall submit an application to the county requesting indigent defense representation and setting forth the specifics supporting such person's need for such indigent defense representation. Such application shall be submitted to such employee of the respective courts as determined by the judge of each such court on a form approved by the county manager. (Ord. of 3-8-2005; Ord. of 5-28-2013) Sec. 2-301. - Application fee. Each applicant for indigent defense services shall pay an application fee of $50.00 to the clerk of the court, or to such other person as may be appointed for such purpose by the judge of such respective courts in which indigent defense representation is being sought. Such fee must be paid at the time the application is submitted. (Ord. of 3-8-2005) Sec. 2-302. - Waiver. The fee required by section 2-301 of this article may be waived only upon order of the presiding judge scheduled to hear the case in which the applicant is seeking a waiver of the application fee. The judge may order waiver of the fee only upon a finding by the court that the defendant is unable to pay the fee or that paying the fee would cause hardship to the defendant. (Ord. of 3-8-2005) Sec. 2-303. - Transfer of funds. Within ten days after the end of each month, funds received by the respective courts as application fees paid under section 2-301 of this article shall remit the total of all application fees collected during the previous calendar month to the governing authority of the county. (Ord. of 3-8-2005) Sec. 2-304. - Separate account. The funds remitted to the governing authority pursuant to section 2-303 of this article shall be maintained in a separate fund for indigent defense services and shall be expended only for the purpose of providing legal representation to indigent defendants in the magistrate court of the county and in the probate court of the county. (Ord. of 3-8-2005) Secs. 2-305—2-399. - Reserved. ARTICLE IX. - PROVISION OF LEGAL DEFENSE FOR ELECTED OFFICIALS, APPOINTED OFFICIALS, AND COUNTY EMPLOYEES
Sec. 2-400. - Definitions. As used in this article, the following words shall have the meanings herein ascribed: County elected or appointed official: Any person elected to any county office, or appointed by the Board of Commissioners of Lee County to any county board, authority, or commission of Lee County. County employee: Any person formerly or presently employed by Lee County, or by a county board, authority or commission. Civil action: Any claim, demand, or cause of action seeking damages, whether such damages are compensatory or punitive, mandamus, injunctive or other relief, that is filed in a federal or state court (1) where a county elected or appointed official or county employee is named as a defendant; and (2) where the actions upon which the claim is based occurred, (a) with respect to a county elected or appointed official, when he or she was acting in the course of his or her duties as an elected or appointed official, and (b) with respect to a county employee, when he or she was acting within the course of his or her employment. The term "civil action" shall only include actions based upon negligence, violation of contract rights, or violation of constitutional or statutory rights of the claimant. Costs of defense: All reasonable costs involved in preparation for and trial of any civil action, including, reasonable attorney's fees, court costs, and out-of-pocket expenses. Good faith: A reasonable belief that the action complained of was proper and within the scope of the official's or employee's duties to Lee County. The existence of a reasonable belief shall be based upon an evaluation of the facts and circumstances known to the official or employee at the time of the occurrence of the action subject to such complaint. (Ord. of 6-19-2007) Sec. 2-401. - Civil actions—Payment of costs of defense. Any county elected or appointed official, and any county employee, against whom any civil action (as herein defined) is brought or threatened by reason of any action taken by such county officer, county appointed official, or county employee taken in good faith in the course of his or her duties shall be indemnified by Lee County from Lee County's general fund for the costs of defense, including reasonable attorney's fees, actually paid or incurred by such county officer, county appointed official, or county employee in connection with proceedings related to the defense or settlement of such action. Such costs of defense shall only be authorized for payment upon compliance with and subject to the following: (1) A detailed written request regarding the payment of costs of defense under this article shall be submitted by the county elected official, county appointed official, or county employee seeking such reimbursement to the county manager, and if, after review of the request, the county manager determines that there is probable cause to believe that such request may be sufficient to authorize payment of the costs of defense under this article, then such request shall be submitted to the board of commissioners for consideration at the next county commission voting meeting which is scheduled to occur no sooner than 30 days of the date such request is submitted. Such written request shall contain, at a minimum, identification of the claimants, the basis of the claim, the reason why the claim cannot be defended by the county attorney or legal counsel hired by the county's liability insurance carrier, the estimate of the total costs of defense that would be paid by the county, and such other information as may be required by the county manager. (2) No such costs shall be paid except upon approval of the governing body of the county. Any attorney's fees paid shall be based upon reasonable hourly rate charges for such attorney and, unless agreed by the governing body, such hourly rate for attorney's fees shall not exceed the normal hourly rate then charged by the county attorney. Fees charged for paralegal time shall be no greater than one-half of the attorney's fees paid to the attorney. The governing body shall be authorized to impose a maximum amount of costs of defense which it will pay in connection with any particular civil action or in connection with any particular county elected official, county appointed official, or county employee, and any approval of the payment of the costs of defense shall not prohibit the governing body from rejecting future payment requests in connection with the same civil action. (3) The attorney selected to provide a defense for the county official, county appointee, or county employee shall be selected by the county official, county appointee, or county employee in his or her sole discretion, and any costs of defense not covered in accord with the provisions of this article shall be the sole responsibility of the county official, county appointee, or county employee, and Lee County shall have no liability therefor. (4) No costs of defense shall be payable hereunder for any such costs that were incurred by the county elected official, appointed official, or county employee prior to the date of approval of the payment of defense costs for the elected official, appointed official, or county employee in connection with the subject civil action unless the governing body determines that the previously incurred costs of defense would have been paid hereunder except for the legal inability of the county elected official, appointed official, or county employee to make such request under this article or for the excusable neglect of the county elected official, appointed official, or county employee in failing to submit such request in a timely manner. (Ord. of 6-19-2007; Ord. of 5-28-2013) Sec. 2-402. - Limitation on hiring outside counsel. Notwithstanding any other provision of this article to the contrary, a count elected official, county appointee, or county employee shall not be authorized to hire or retain outside counsel under this article where a civil action is being defended or is to be defended by the county attorney or by legal counsel retained by the county's liability insurance carrier unless there are claims raised in the civil action which are not claims covered by the county's liability insurance and the county attorney is unable to defend such claims due to a conflict of interest or for some other reason as determined by either the county attorney or the board of commissioners. In such event, outside counsel shall only provide a defense in connection with such claims that are not covered by such insurance and shall not, in any manner, replace or duplicate the legal defense being provided by the county attorney or the attorney hired by the county's liability insurance carrier. Unless there is a conflict of interest, if outside counsel is hired, the county attorney shall monitor the legal proceedings, and shall make such reports to the board of commissioners as he or she may deem appropriate or as requested by the board regarding the civil action. Any outside counsel hired under this article shall cooperate with the county attorney in connection with proceedings in the civil action, subject only to the provisions of Rules of Professional Conduct of the Georgia Bar Association. (Ord. of 6-19-2007) Sec. 2-403. - Counter-claims and cross claims. Any counter-claim or cross claim filed by or on behalf of a county official, a county appointee, or a county employee in a civil action shall be filed and prosecuted at the sole cost and expense of the county official, county appointee, or county employee filing such counter-claim or cross claim, and Lee County shall not have any responsibility for the payment of any costs, judgments, or other expenses, including attorney's fees, incurred as a result of or in connection with such counter-claim or cross claim. (Ord. of 6-19-2007) Sec. 2-404. - Unreasonable or excessive legal fees. Nothing in this article shall require Lee County to pay any attorney's fees, court costs, or out-of-pocket expenses on behalf of a county elected official, county appointee, or county employee where the governing body determines that such fees, costs, or expenses are unreasonable or excessive. (Ord. of 6-19-2007) Sec. 2-405. - Waiver of immunity. The provisions of this article shall not be construed as a waiver of any grant of immunity to Lee County, its elected officials, its appointees, or its or employees under the federal or state constitution, under any federal or state statute, or under any rule of common law. (Ord. of 6-19-2007) Sec. 2-406. - Contract rights. This article shall not be construed as creating or establishing any property rights or contractual rights between Lee County and any elected official, appointed official, or employee of Lee County. As a result, the provisions of this article may be amended, modified, revised, or repealed at any time by the governing body of the county, and any amendment, modification, revision, or repeal shall become effective as of the date that such amendment, modification, revision, or repeal is approved by the governing body and shall apply in all respects to any claims for reimbursement for costs of defense submitted from and after such date of amendment, modification, revision, or repeal, whether or not such civil action was pending before the date of such repeal or became pending after the date of such repeal. (Ord. of 6-19-2007) Sec. 2-407. - Method of payment of costs of defense. Subject to the provisions of section 2-401(2) of this article, where the governing body has agreed to pay the costs of defense for a county elected official, county appointee, or county employee, invoices for such charges shall be submitted to the county manager on a monthly basis for approval by the governing body, and no such invoices shall be paid without the governing body's approval. (Ord. of 6-19-2007; Ord. of 5-28-2013) Sec. 2-408. - Assignment; guaranty. Nothing in this article shall be construed to authorize an assignment of any right to receive reimbursement for costs of defense by any county elected official, county appointee, or county employee to any third party. In addition, this article shall not be construed as a guaranty of payment of any costs of defense by Lee County to any county elected official, county appointed official, county employee, or any third party. (Ord. of 6-19-2007) Sec. 2-409. - No condonation or waiver; payment of judgments. (a) Payment of costs of defense under the terms of this article shall not be construed as a condonation of the action of any county elected official, county appointee, or county employee; nor shall payment of costs of defense under the terms of this article act as a waiver of any right that Lee County may have to remove county elected officials, county appointees, or county employees from office under applicable law or local ordinances; nor shall this article be construed to authorize the payment of costs of defense in connection with an action brought by Lee County or any of its boards, commissions, and authorities against any county elected official, county appointee, or county employee. (b) Nothing in this article shall be construed to impose any liability upon Lee County, or its elected officials, agents, or employees for the payment or satisfaction of any judgment, or of any portion thereof, rendered against any county elected official, county appointed official, or county employee in any civil action. (Ord. of 6-19-2007) Sec. 2-410. - Authorization for article. This article is authorized pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 45-9-21, and shall be construed in all events in accord with that statute, court decisions, and attorney general opinions (both official and unofficial) construing such statute. (Ord. of 6-19-2007) Secs. 2-411—2-449. - Reserved. ARTICLE X. - PROVISIONS OF FUNDS TO PROVIDE FOR BURIAL OR INTERMENT FOR CREMATION OF DECEASED INDIGENT PERSONS
Sec. 2-450. - Funding to provide interment or cremation for deceased indigent persons. Pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-12-5, Lee County shall pay an amount not to exceed $500.00 to provide a decent interment or cremation of a deceased indigent person or to reimburse such person as may have expended the cost of such interment or cremation voluntarily; provided, however, that any such amount paid pursuant to this article shall not exceed the lessor of the actual cost of interment or cremation. ( Ord. of 6-9-2015 ) Sec. 2-451. - Annual appropriation of funds or indigent burials. The board of commissions shall, in their annual general fund budget, provide appropriation for the payment of such amounts during the fiscal year covered by such budget. ( Ord. of 6-9-2015 ) Sec. 2-452. - Approval of payment. No payment under this article shall be made without the written approval of the county manager, and in no event shall any such payment under this article exceed $500.00 per burial or cremation. ( Ord. of 6-9-2015 )

div.head: Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Sale of alcoholic beverages prohibited on adult entertainment premises, § 10-42; businesses, ch. 22; purchase or possession of alcohol by underage persons unlawful, § 46-2; disorderly conduct while intoxicated, § 46-4; public drunkenness, § 46-5. State Law reference— Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq. Editor's note— An Ord. of Jan. 13, 2000(1) repealed chapter 6, sections 6-1—6-9, in its entirety and replaced it with a new chapter 6. Former chapter 6 pertained to similar material and derived from an Ord. of 8-6-1985; an Ord. of 12-20-1994, §§ 1—5; and a Res. of 7-10-1997.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 6-1. - Purposes. (a) The purposes of this chapter shall include, without necessarily being limited to, the following: (1) Compliance with and effectuation of the general state law; (2) Prevention and control of the sale of alcoholic beverages by unfit persons; (3) Insuring that any licenses issued for the consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises are issued only to a legitimate restaurant or private club as defined in this chapter; (4) The protection of schools, homes, churches, parks, and other institutions; (5) Protection of the public health, safety, and welfare. (b) To the maximum extent permissible under state and federal law, the business of selling alcoholic beverages shall under this chapter be considered to be a privilege to be accorded in conformity with the foregoing and other public policies of the city, rather than a right. (Ord. of 1-13-2000(1)) Sec. 6-2. - Definitions. (a) Unless a contrary intention is clearly apparent from the context, the following terms used in this chapter shall have the following meaning: Alcohol means ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl, spirits or wine, from whatever source or whatever process produced. Alcoholic beverage means and includes all alcohol, malt beverages, distilled spirits, wine and fortified wines defined in this section. Board of county commissioners means chairman and county commissioners of Lee County, Georgia. County means Lee County and when used in geographical sense means the unincorporated area of Lee County. County building official means the chief building inspector of Lee County. Distilled spirits means any alcoholic beverage obtained by distillation or containing more than 21 percent alcohol by volume including, but not limited to, all fortified wines. Fortified wine means any alcoholic beverage containing more than 21 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries, or grapes either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. "Fortified wine" includes, but is not limited to, brandy. Interest includes any pecuniary interest and any ownership interest, whether present or future, whole or partial, legal or beneficial, contingent or vested, direct or indirect, and any right, power, or authority or control. Licensed premises includes not only the room wherein alcoholic beverages are sold or served, but also the entire building in which such room is located, except that when such a room is located in a hotel, motel, or similar facility or in a shopping center only such room and any adjoining storage, office, toilet, and other similar rooms shall constitute the "licensed premises." Such terms shall also include patios, decks, and other similar appurtenances associated with the licensed premises, but shall not include public, semi-public or private parking lots. Licensee includes an individual licensee, and in the case of a partnership or corporation includes both the partnership or corporation and the named licensee. Majority stockholder means the person, if any, who owns more than 50 percent of the voting stock of a corporation; if no person owns more than 50 percent of the voting of a corporation, the "majority stockholder" is the person owning more of the voting stock than any other person; and if two or more persons each own the same amount of the voting stock of a corporation and each own more of the voting stock than any other person, then any one of such persons may act as the "majority stockholder." Malt beverage means fermented beverage made in whole or in part from malt or any similar fermented substance, also sometimes referred to as "beer". Mixed drink means any distilled spirits served for consumption on the premises, whether or not diluted by water or any other substance. Named licensee means the person acting as such for a partnership or corporation pursuant to section 6-27. Person includes a corporation, partnership, association, club or institution. (b) Unless a contrary intention is clearly apparent form the context, any term used in this chapter shall have the same meaning as when used in comparable provision of the Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, as appearing in the Official Code of Georgia, Title 3. (c) As used in this chapter, the singular and plural shall each include the other, the masculine and feminine shall each include the other, and any verb tense may include any other verb tense. (d) As used in this chapter, the term "may" is permissive and the term "shall" is mandatory. (Ord. of 1-13-2000(1)) Sec. 6-3. - Violations; penalty. (a) Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, in a court of competent jurisdiction, be punished as provided in this Code, which may include a fine or imprisonment, or both such fine and imprisonment. Any such punishment, if imposed, shall be in addition to and not in lieu of any license suspension or revocation under this chapter. (b) The violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be grounds for suspension or revocation or any alcoholic beverage license issued hereunder, as follows: (1) For the first offense, there may be imposed a fine of up to $500.00 and/or a suspension of all alcoholic beverage licenses issued by the county for a period of not exceeding ten days. (2) For the second offense, occurring within one year of the date of occurrence of the first offense, there may be imposed a fine of up to $1,000.00 and/or suspension of all alcoholic beverage licenses issued by the county for a period not exceeding 30 days. (3) For the third and any subsequent offenses occurring within one year of the date of occurrence of the first offense, all alcoholic beverage licenses issued by the county shall be revoked for a minimum of 60 days before the license holder can reapply for a license at the same location. (Ord. of 1-13-2000(1)) Secs. 6-4—6-25. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - LICENSING
Sec. 6-26. - Required classifications, etc. (a) Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer to sell any alcoholic beverages within the county except under a valid license issued under this chapter and in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. (b) Pay schedule. License fees shall be payable in advance for an entire year beginning January 1 and ending December 31 of the same year. If an initial license fee is paid after January 1, the license fees shall be prorated on a monthly basis for each moth or portion of a month left between the date of payment and December 31. The suspension or revocation of any license granted pursuant tot his article shall not entitle the licensee to a return of any portion of the license fee. (c) License fee. Classes of licenses issued under this chapter, activities permitted and regulated thereunder, and the annual license fees shall be as follows: (1) Retail off-premises licenses: a. Retail sales for off-premises consumption of malt beverages ..... $250.00 b. Retail sales for off-premises consumption of wine ..... 250.00 (2) Retail consumption on-the-premises licenses: a. Pouring license for malt beverage only on the premises ..... 250.00 b. Pouring license for wine only on the premises ..... 250.00 c. Pouring license for consumption of distilled spirits only on the premises ..... 1,500.00 d. Pouring license for retail sale of distilled spirits, wine and malt beverages by the drink ..... 2,000.00 (3) Wholesale licenses: Resident wholesale dealer's license: wholesale of distilled spirits, wine, and malt beverages by a wholesale dealer having a place of business in the county ..... 1,000.00 (d) Application fees. Each application for a license under this chapter shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee in the following amount: (1) Sale off-premises of package malt beverages and wine license ..... $75.00 (2) Consumption on-the premises pouring license for distilled spirits, beer and wine ..... 150.00 (e) Payment of fees. All application fees for license applicants shall be paid at the time the application is filed and shall not be refunded. All license fees shall be paid upon approval of the license application and no license shall be issued until the payment of all applicable license fees. (Ord. of 1-13-2000(1)) Sec. 6-27. - Procedure for issuance. (a) A license issued to an individual shall be issued in the name of the individual. A license issued to a partnership shall be issued in the name of the partnership and in the name of one of the partners who shall be the named licensee. A license issued to a corporation having as its principal business the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be issued in the name of the corporation and in the name of the majority stockholder or principal officer of the corporation; and such majority stockholder or officer shall be the named licensee. A license issued to a corporation having as its principal business an activity other than the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be issued in the name of the corporation and in the name of the officer or employee of the corporation primarily responsible for the operation of the licensed premises; and such officer or employee shall be the named licensee. (b) In the case of a partnership, each partner shall join as an applicant for the license and each partner must meet the qualifications of an individual licensee, as provided herein. (c) In the case of a corporation having as its principal business the sale of alcoholic beverages, the majority stockholder and each principal officer of the corporation shall join as applicants for the license; and each such person must meet the qualifications of an individual licensee, as provided herein, except for the residency requirement which shall be required only for the named licensee. (d) In the case of a corporation having as its principal business an activity other than the sale of alcoholic beverages, the officer or employee who is to be the named licensee shall be the applicant and must meet the qualifications of an individual licensee as provided herein; provided, however, that the county building official may require the fingerprinting and investigation of officers and shareholders of the corporation if such official deems it necessary in undertaking his investigation. (e) In the case of a partnership, each partner shall be responsible for the actions of the named licensee and the conduct of the licensed business. In the case of a corporation, the corporation shall be responsible for the actions of the named licensee and the conduct of the licensed business. (f) Each licensee shall also be responsible for the actions of each employee employed by the licensee and the licensed business during such employee's working hours. (Ord. of 1-13-2000(1)) Sec. 6-28. - Qualifications. (a) A licensee must be at least 21 years of age, of good moral character, and a citizen of the United States or a legal resident of the United States; provided, however, that any license issued to a person who is a legal resident of the United States shall only be valid during the term of such person's legal residency, and if such legal residency status is lost, revoked, or terminated, then such license shall be deemed revoked as of the date of loss of such legal residency status by the licensee. (b) A licensee shall not have been convicted within the past five years of any felony, any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, or any other misdemeanor involving a violation of county alcohol ordinances within the past two years. This subsection shall apply with respect to the laws of this state, other states, the United States, and other countries. A plea of nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond shall be considered a conviction for purposes of this subsection. The county building official may recommend the waiver of the conviction of a misdemeanor for purposes of this subsection if the county building official determines that the misdemeanor does not have a bearing on the applicant's fitness for a license, subject to the approval of the board of county commissioners at the time the license is issued. (c) A licensee shall not have been denied or had revoked, within the 12 months immediately preceding his application, any license to sell alcoholic beverages issued by any governmental entity. (d) A licensee shall be the owner of the premises to be licensed or the holder of a lease thereon for substantially the same period to be covered by the license. (e) No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink for consumption on the premises shall be issued to any applicant for a location or facility that does not meet the requirements of a private club, restaurant or country club as defined in this chapter. (Ord. of 1-13-2000(1); Ord. of 12-6-2004(1)) Sec. 6-29. - Initial application procedures. (a) Application for a license for the retail sale of wine and malt beverages in the county shall be filed with the county building official upon forms prescribed by the county and made available at the county administration building. The application shall be subscribed by the application under oath and fully completed and executed. At a minimum, the applicant shall be required to provide the following information with the application: (1) The employment history for the previous five years of the applicant, its chief operating officers or partners, including names and addresses of previous employers, places of doing business, and experience in the field for which the applicant seeks an alcoholic beverage license; (2) Proof of liability insurance in the amount of $100,000.00, and worker's compensation insurance where applicable, effective for at least one year from the date of application; (3) Written consent for the county to receive the criminal history of the applicant (the chief operating official and partners in the case of firms, corporations, or partnerships; (4) Permanent address and phone number for the person making the application; (5) A photograph of the applicant or chief operating officers or partners of the entity making the application; and (6) Whether the applicant seeks permission to sell alcohol for consumption on the premises. (b) There shall be attached to the application a bank money order, certified check or like remittance of the application fee in full. (c) As a prerequisite to the issuance of the license, the applicant shall furnish a complete set of fingerprints to be forwarded to the state bureau of investigation which shall search the files and forward the fingerprints the Federal Bureau of Investigation to determine past criminal activity. (d) At some time during the two weeks prior to the board of county commissioners consideration of an initial or renewal application, the county building official shall cause to be published in the county legal organ one time a notice of the application, including the name of the applicant, the location of the business, the type of license applied for and the date and time of the county commissioner's hearing thereon. (e) Failure to fully complete and execute an application for a license or to furnish accurately all data, information and records required by the application form as well as failure to accompany the application with the payment of the prescribed fee shall be deemed just cause for denying the application with prejudice. (f) After his investigation, the county building official shall make a recommendation to the board of commissioners at their next regularly scheduled meeting regarding whether to approve or deny the application. The board of commissioners shall be authorized, but not required, to vote on approval or denial of the application at the meeting at which the county building official's recommendation is made. The decision to grant or deny the application must be based upon the best interest of the citizens of Lee County as determined by consideration of the following factors that are determined to be relevant to the applicant: (1) The existence or non-existence of verifiable information regarding the applicant's work history, status, experience, and reputation; (2) The history of the applicant, if any, in engaging in fraudulent or criminal activities; (3) Compliance with the application requirements; (4) Adequate and satisfactory reference response; (5) Proximity of the proposed business to densely populated residential districts; (6) Compliance with zoning regulations; (7) Safety of the premises from which the business shall operate; (8) Past compliance, or past failure to comply, with state and local laws, regulations, and ordinances; and (9) Whether or not the business is located within prohibited distances as provided in section 6-56 of this Code. (Ord. of 1-13-2000(1); Ord. of 8-11-2015 ) Sec. 6-30. - Renewal. (a) All alcoholic beverage licensees shall be required to apply for renewal of their licenses annually on forms prescribed by the county building official and must comply with all provisions of this article, with the exception that publication of notice nor a public hearing shall not be required for renewal of a license unless there has been a change of ownership of the business or other interests therein. (b) Upon application for renewal and completion of the building official's investigation, the building official shall make a recommendation to the county commissioners at their next regularly scheduled meeting, and the board shall be authorized to act at that time, either granting or denying the renewal application. Nothing shall prohibit the county commission from voting to grant or deny more than one renewal application at a time. (c) No application for renewal may be approved until all reports to be filed by the licensee hereunder are filed. (d) At the time of application for a renewal of license for any consumption on the licensed premises, the applicant shall also file with the renewal application a notarized statement or affidavit setting forth the total percentage of sales from food prepared on the premises, non alcoholic beverages consumed on the premises, and alcoholic beverages consumed on the premises for the previous 12 months. (Ord. of 1-13-2000(1)) Sec. 6-31. - Transfer. (a) Except as provided in this section, no license shall be transferable to any other person or location. (b) If a licensee seeks to move his place of business from the licensed premises to another place within the county, the application process shall be the same as the process for obtaining an original license, and the applicable application fees shall be paid at the time the application is filed; provided, however, that no additional license fees shall be payable by the licensee for the current year. (c) In the case of death of an owner of a license or of a financial interest therein, such license or interest therein may be transferred to the administrator, executor, or adult heir or heirs of the deceased unless the county building official determines that such a transfer would cause or result in a violation of this chapter. If the proposed transferee cannot meet all the requirements of this chapter, then the license transfer shall not be approved and the license shall be revoked. (d) Nothing in this section shall prohibit one or more partners in a partnership from retiring therefrom in favor of one or more of the other partners; provided such withdrawal shall not, without application for an issuance of a new license, introduce any new partner or result in any new person acquiring an interest in the licensed business. (e) Where a license is issued to a corporation having as its principal business an activity other than the sale alcoholic beverages, a change in the named licensee may be permitted by the county building official upon the payment of the required application fees, if the new named licensee meets the requirements of new license applicants. (f) In the circumstances described in subsections (c), (d) and (e) of this section, the license shall be revoked if the county building official determines that the change results in a failure to meet the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. of 1-13-2000(1)) Sec. 6-32. - Change in business ownership. (a) If any licensee withdraws from, sells or otherwise transfers the licensee's interest in the licensed business, the licensee shall immediately notify the county building official and surrender the license. (b) In the case of such a withdrawal, transfer, or sale, a new application shall be made as for an original license. (Ord. of 1-13-2000(1)) Sec. 6-33. - Temporary license. (a) A temporary license may be issued by the county building official if, in his judgment, the denial of a temporary license would create an undue hardship such as the closing of an existing business. The temporary license shall be issued for an extra fee of $50.00 for a 90 day period. No temporary license may be issued for a location not previously licensed. (b) A temporary license may be revoked, with or without cause, by the county building official at any time, and the grant or denial of a temporary license shall not affect or have any bearing upon the grant or denial of an annual license. (Ord. of 1-13-2000(1)) Sec. 6-34. - License suspension or revocation. (a) A license may be suspended or revoked by the county building official as provided in section 6-3 of this Code, for any violation of this chapter and/or other county ordinances relating to alcoholic beverages, for any violation of state or federal law relating to alcoholic beverages, for any material misrepresentation or omission in the application for the license, or at any time when the licensee or the licensed business ceases to meet the eligibility requirements for an alcoholic beverage license. (b) The building official is authorized to suspend the sale of alcoholic beverages for any emergency situation, as officially declared by the board of commissioners, where the building official deems such suspension necessary for the immediate protection of public health, safety, or welfare. Such suspension may be made effective immediately and may remain in force until the building official determines that the emergency situation is concluded or until directed by the board of commissioners to rescind such suspension, but in no event shall such, emergency suspension exceed 20 calendar days. (c) Prior to suspending or revoking a license, except in emergency situations described in subsection (b) above, the building official shall give at least five days prior written notice to the licensee of the time, place, and purpose of the hearing at which such suspension or revocation shall be considered. Service of such notice shall be perfected by personal service at the licensed premises upon the named licensee or an employee of the licensee at such location by the county sheriff or his lawful deputy, or, if personal service may not be so perfected, by tacking a copy of the notice to the door of the licensed premises. In addition to the other methods of service, the notice shall also be mailed to the licensee at the address of the licensee contained in the most recent license application on file in the building official's office, certified mail, return receipt requested. (d) Any licensee where licenses or revoked by the building official may appeal each suspension or revocation to the board of commissioners. Any such approval must be filed within ten working days from the date of the written decision by the building official. Such appeal must be made in writing, must be filed with the county clerk within such ten day period, and must set forth the general grounds or basis of the appeal. The suspensions or revocation shall be held in abeyance until the conclusion of the appeal. Any such appeal shall be considered by the board of commissioners within 45 days after the date of filing thereof. The licensee shall be given at least five days prior written notice of the date, time and location of the hearing on the appeal. Service of such notice shall be in the same manner as set forth in subsection (c) hereof. At the hearing, the board of commissioners shall take such testimony under oath and consider such other evidence as it may deem appropriate. The board of commissioners may then affirm, reverse or modify the decision of the building official, but it may only reverse or modify each decision if the board of commissioners finds that the building officials' decision was improper, clearly erroneous, or based upon insufficient evidence. Notice of the board of commissioner's decision shall be provided in writing to the licensee. (Ord. of 1-13-2000(1)) Sec. 6-35. - License revocation. (a) A license shall be revoked if: (1) The licensee's state alcoholic beverage license is revoked. (2) Operation of the licensed activity is not commenced within six months after the license is issued. (3) Operation of the licensed activity is commenced and then discontinued for a period of 30 days unless approved by the county building official. (4) The licensed business declares bankruptcy or receivership, or fails to properly account for, file, report or pay any excise tax levied under this chapter. (5) The licensed businesses fails to properly account for, file, report and maintain any records or remit any license fee imposed or taxes required under this chapter. (6) Payment of the annual renewal license fee is not received by the county within the time prescribed. (7) The named licensee is convicted of a felony by a court of competent jurisdiction. (b) The provisions regarding notice and hearing contained in section 6-34(e) shall apply to revocations pursuant to this section. (Ord. of 1-13-2000(1)) Sec. 6-36. - Licenses for state authority operating park in Lee County. Notwithstanding any other provision of Chapter 6 of the Lee County Code of Ordinances, any authority created under state law which is a public body corporate and politic, is a public corporation of the State of Georgia, and operates a park located either wholly or partially in Lee County as the term "park" is defined in Georgia Laws 1979, page 4515, shall be authorized to apply for and obtain an alcoholic beverage license for the sale and serving of beer, wine, and mixed drinks for consumption only on the premises of such park. Any such license issued in accord with this section shall be termed an "authority license." The following shall apply with respect to such authority license: (1) Such licenses may be issued by the county manager, or his designee. (2) Prior to the issuance of an authority license, the chief executive officer of the authority shall submit to the county manager an application for an authority license. Such application shall be submitted on such forms as may be furnished by the county manager. There shall be no application fee required in connection with such application. (3) No background checks or fingerprint checks shall be required with respect to the person signing the application; however, such person shall be responsible for insuring that the authority complies with all statutes, ordinances, rules, and regulations relating to the sale and serving of alcoholic beverages in accord with the terms of such authority license. (4) The authority license shall authorize the licensee to sell or serve alcoholic beverages for consumption only on the premises of the park operated by such authority. No alcoholic beverages shall be sold or served by any third party at the authority's park under the auspices of the authority license; however, the authority shall be authorized to allow the serving of beer, wine, and mixed drinks at the park by third parties where such alcoholic beverages are served in connection with or as a part of a meeting, a wedding, or similar event. (5) Alcoholic beverages shall only be sold or served by the authority licensee at such times as alcoholic beverages are authorized to be sold and served in accord with the provisions of Chapter 6 of the Code of Ordinances of Lee County. No alcoholic beverages may be served by the authority licensee at any location which is within any of the prohibited distances from church buildings, school buildings, education buildings, school grounds, or college campuses as established under Chapter 6 of the Code of Ordinances of Lee County. (6) The license issued under this section shall expire on December 31 of the calendar year in which such license was issued, and the applicant shall be required to make application for such license on an annual basis. Upon the issuance of a license under this section, the licensee shall comply with all state and local laws, rules, and regulations with respect to the purchase, sale, and dispensing of alcoholic beverages applicable thereto. (7) In the event that the licensee violates any of the provisions of the county's alcoholic beverage ordinance, such permit shall be subject to suspension or revocation in accord with the procedures established in section 6-34 of the Code of Ordinances of Lee County. (Ord. of 9-12-2006, § 1; Ord. of 5-28-2013) Sec. 6-37. - Alcoholic beverage caterers. (a) For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply: (1) Person means any individual, company, corporation, association, partnership, or other legal entity. (2) Food caterer means any person who, for consideration, prepares food for consumption off the premises. (3) Licensed alcoholic beverage caterer means any person licensed for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the state and by a local governmental entity within this state and who possesses a valid alcoholic beverage license issued by a local government in the state authorizing such person to sell or dispense alcoholic beverages by the drink off licensed premises and in connection with an authorized catered function. (4) Authorized catered function means an event at a location not otherwise licensed for consumption of alcoholic beverages by the drink at which alcoholic beverages are furnished, sold, dispensed, or provided free of charge to persons present at the event, by the drink, pursuant to a permit obtained under this section. (b) (1) Licenses for alcoholic beverage caterers may be obtained for the purpose of selling or dispensing alcoholic beverages by the drink on premises on which authorized catered functions are to be held. Such licenses shall be annual licenses and may be obtained only by those persons, firms, or corporations already licensed by the county for the sale of alcoholic beverages at retail by the drink. The procedures for securing such licenses shall be the same procedures required for the securing of an alcoholic beverage license for the sale of mixed drinks for consumption on the licensed premises where served as provided in this chapter; provided, however, that no alcoholic beverage caterers license shall be required where the alcoholic beverages served at the catered function are purchased and provided by the sponsor of the event or function. (2) Each alcoholic beverage caterer licensee shall pay an annual license fee which shall be paid at the same time that the licensee pays the annual fees to obtain the alcoholic beverage caterer's regular alcoholic beverage license. Such license fee shall be in the amount of $500.00 per year, and there shall be no proration or refund with respect to any such license obtained during a calendar year. (c) Before a licensed alcoholic beverage caterer may sell or dispense alcoholic beverages at any authorized catered function, such caterer shall obtain an event permit under this section. The application for an event permit shall include the name of the alcoholic beverage caterer, the caterer's license number, and the date, address, time of the event, the purpose of the event, and the duration of the event. No permit fee shall be charged for the alcoholic beverage caterers licensed by the county. For caterers licensed by jurisdictions other than the county, a fee of $50.00 per event permit shall be charged. No permit shall be issued to any person under this section who does not hold an alcoholic beverage caterers license from a local jurisdiction in the State of Georgia. The permit shall be kept in the vehicle used to transport alcoholic beverages to the event at all times during which the permit is in effect. (d) Caterers licensed by a jurisdiction other than the county shall maintain a record of all alcoholic beverages transported into the county for the event and shall pay an excise tax to the county covering all such beverages at such rates as provided by county ordinance or resolution. Failure to report and remit the tax within seven calendar days of the conclusion of the event shall be grounds for denial of subsequent permits to that caterer for similar events. (e) Alcoholic beverage caterers licensed by the county shall maintain a record of all alcoholic beverages transported for each event, by event, and shall make report and remittance of all required excise and other taxes with their regular monthly reports to the county. (f) No alcoholic beverages shall be transported, distributed, or sold to any location other than licensed locations in the county, except to authorized catered functions, unless otherwise authorized by this chapter or by state law. (g) The hours and days of sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages under this section shall be the same as provided for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink as provided in this chapter. (h) No licensed alcoholic beverage caterer shall employ any person under 21 years of age to dispense, serve, sell, or handle alcoholic beverages at authorized catered functions. (i) As a condition of permit issuance, alcoholic beverage caterers licensed by jurisdictions other than the county shall be provided with a copy of the county's alcoholic beverage ordinances and shall indicate, by signature, that they have received such ordinances and acknowledge the applicability of such ordinances to their operations within the jurisdiction of the county. (j) In addition to the foregoing, compliance with all applicable local ordinances and resolutions relating to alcoholic beverages in effect in the city, a licensed alcoholic beverage caterer shall comply with all provisions of O.C.G.A. § 3-11-4 and with the Department of Revenue Regulations Chapter 560-2-10. Any failure to comply with such state law, regulations, or local ordinances or resolutions shall subject the alcoholic beverage caterer licensee to disciplinary proceedings regarding such licensee's license as provided in Chapter 6 of this Code. (Ord. of 10-25-2011(1)) Sec. 6-38. - Alcoholic beverage permit for bona fide non-profit civic organizations. (a) In accord with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 3-9-3, the county shall be authorized to issue a permit to a bona fide non-profit civic organization to sell and serve alcoholic beverages for consumption only on the premises where sold for a period not to exceed three days, subject to compliance with the provisions of this section.
